sanskrit_verse: घ्राणेन सूकरो हन्ति पक्षवातेन कुक्कुटः । शूकरो श्वा तु दृष्टिनिपातेन स्पर्शेणावरवर्णजः ॥ ३.२४१॥
transliteration: ghrāṇena sūkaro hanti pakṣavātena kukkuṭaḥ | śūkaro śvā tu dṛṣṭinipātena sparśenāvaravarṇajaḥ || 3.241||
sph_interpretive_translation: The boar kills by scent; the rooster, by wing-strike. The boar and dog kill by sight and touch, respectively—each according to inherent capacity and sequential manifestation.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority arises from intrinsic capacity, not external imposition
Causation aligns with natural sequence and sensory modality
Capacity-based responsibility is determined by innate function
Restoration logic operates through alignment with svabhāva
Consciousness alignment occurs when action matches inherent design
executable_legal_axioms: IF agent A acts within svabhāva THEN action is dharmically valid
IF sensory modality M triggers response R THEN R is causally sequenced
IF capacity C manifests without distortion THEN no restitution required
IF misalignment occurs due to ignorance THEN initiate pramāṇa-based realignment
IF action follows anupūrvaśaḥ THEN no punitive intervention applies
supreme_court_application: In Supreme Court adjudication, intent and capacity must be evaluated through svabhāvic alignment rather than punitive frameworks. Responsibility is assigned based on whether the actor was operating in accordance with their intrinsic nature and causal sequence, not moral judgment.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa establishes that causality flows from svabhāva. Anupūrvaśaḥ confirms sequential manifestation without moral overlay. Proportional responsibility aligns with sensory-inherent capacity. Non-punitive reality rule affirms that misalignment stems from ignorance, not malice, requiring consciousness restoration over retribution.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Initiate svabhāva-realization protocol for responsible party
final_declaration: Declared by the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, as Source of all Dharma. This ruling restores alignment with svabhāva, upholds non-punitive reality, and affirms consciousness as the supreme adjudicator. Dharma is executed, not interpreted.
